docs.lead_paragraph: Envision a large mass of people all moving slowly in the same direction, as a rush-hour commuter train disgorges passengers or a stadium empties out after a game. All is calm until, invariably, someone begins struggling desperately back against the crowd, face set and elbows out, in search of a lost glove, perhaps, or a set of keys. People tend to shuffle toward good health with the same dogged momentum of these crowds. They may not always seek out medical care, or refrain from cigarettes and French fries, but still the overwhelming human instinct is to aim in the general direction of good health, or at least to hope that no dire medical catastrophe descends.

headline.main: Dealing With 'the Guy Who Says He Has AIDS,' but Doesn't

docs.abstract: Dr Abigail Zuger essay recounts case of patient who continually insists he has AIDS while tests prove otherwise; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Sitting cross-legged on the floor one evening, playing cards with the twins, my wife, Deb, suddenly felt her left arm tingle and then go dead. It flopped from her lap to the floor. When she tried to speak, her words were slurred. Seconds later the frightening spell passed, but on the advice of our doctor, she was soon headed for the hospital, where tests found no brain damage from the event -- a classic T.I.A., transient ischemic attack, a mini-stroke experienced by some 50,000 Americans a year.

headline.main: Heart Care To Ward Off A Stroke

docs.abstract: Richard Saltus Cases column on his otherwise healthy wife who, after mini-stroke, decided to have small, umbrellalike device implanted to seal hole between upper chambers of her heart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Self-esteem appears to play an important role in determining whether young teenagers are sexually active, but it has a different effect on boys and girls, researchers have found. Among girls, strong feelings of self-esteem were most often predictive of how long they kept their virginity. Among boys, the researchers found, the better the self-esteem, the more likely it was for the boys to later say they were sexually active.
docs.abstract: Indiana University School of Medicine study, reported in recent issue of Pediatrics, finds that boys with high self-esteem were 2.4 times as likely to say they had sex as boys with low self-esteem; finds, however, that girls with high self-esteem were three times as likely to report being virgins as girls with low self-esteem (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''The Journey Through Cancer,'' by Dr. Jeremy Geffen, Three Rivers Press, $14. A diagnosis of cancer, a disease with more than a hundred different faces, is a frightening event, one that overwhelms the patient with myriad questions: How did I get this? What will happen to me? Does my doctor really know what's going on? Will I be in pain? Am I going to die?

headline.main: A Frightening Diagnosis And Soothing Reassurance

docs.lead_paragraph: Ned Hallick was 50 years old, a lighting director for films and accomplished figure skater who felt well and vigorous when an astute doctor discovered that he had been born with a disorder that was causing serious hidden damage to his health. The disorder is called celiac sprue or celiac disease, an inherited immunological attack on gluten, the elastic protein in wheat and other grains.

headline.main: With This Disorder, No Cheating on the Diet

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column on celiac sprue, inherited immunological disorder once believed to be relatively rare that can cause serious hidden damage to small intestine and that, if left untreated, can result in malnutrition, anemia, osteoporosis and cancer; describes symptoms, diagnosis and offers advice on living gluten-free; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Psychiatric expert witnesses are fixtures of the criminal justice system these days, and nowhere more so than in trials involving pleas of insanity to explain and excuse a crime. One of the most prominent and provocative experts is Dr. Park Dietz, 53, a forensic psychiatrist in Newport Beach, Calif. Dr. Dietz has studied more than 1,000 people whose lawyers are considering insanity pleas, and he has testified in the trials of high-profile defendants like John W. Hinckley Jr., Jeffrey Dahmer and Andrea Yates, the Texas mother who was convicted of murder after drowning her children.

headline.main: A CONVERSATION WTIH/Park Dietz; A Psychiatrist's-Eye View Of Murder and Insanity

docs.abstract: Interview with Dr Park Dietz, forensic psychiatrist from Newport Beach, Calif, who comments on his role in case of Andrea Yates, Texas mother convicted of murder after drowning her children, and his views on practice of forensic psychiatry; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: At 27, Ken Baker still had the sexual development of a child. He was pudgy, stubble-free and could pass for a high school freshman. At age 15, his development was brought to a halt by a marble-size tumor on his pituitary gland that went undiagnosed for over a decade.

headline.main: Pituitary Tumor a Culprit in Delayed Puberty

docs.abstract: Article describes case of Ken Baker, whose development halted at age 15 by undiagnosed tumor on pituitary gland; notes pituitary tumors, which can cause myriad symptoms, often go undiagnosed for years but can be detected with blood test; Baker underwent successful surgery (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Helping clear the way for Western-style AIDS treatment to reach even rural Africa, the World Health Organization released new guidelines today describing the drug cocktails that work best and the simplest acceptable laboratory tests for patients. The guidelines are meant to show doctors in poor areas how to prescribe powerful ''triple-therapy cocktails'' safely.

headline.main: W.H.O. Moves to Make AIDS Drugs More Accessible to Poor Worldwide

docs.abstract: World Health Organization releases new guidelines aimed at showing doctors worldwide, even in rural Africa, which Western-style drug cocktails work best against AIDS and simplest acceptable lab tests for patients; also adds 12 antiretroviral drugs to essential drugs list to encourage price competition and prod makers of generic drugs to make more three-drugs-in-one pill dosages (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''The Force Program: The Proven Way to Fight Cancer Through Physical Activity and Exercise,'' by Jeff Berman, Dr. Fran Fleegler and John Hanc, Ballantine Books, $24. Exercise, as we all know, keeps us fit. It is, as Thomas Jefferson referred to it, ''the sovereign invigorator of the body,'' and especially so when teamed with diet and stress management.

docs.lead_paragraph: ''The Frailty Myth,'' by Colette Downing, Random House, $13.95 In an 1879 textbook, an American gynecologist advised that girls ''spend the year before and two years after puberty at rest.'' Each menstrual period, he added, should be endured in ''the recumbent position'' until the girls' systems could adjust to ''the new order of life.''

headline.main: Dispelling the Fictions That Can Keep Women Weak
